title: Group of orcas on the hunt for food off the Shetland coast
title_page: Group of orcas on the hunt for food off the Shetland coast | Daily Mail Online
text:
A group of killer whales performed a spectacular show after they surfaced just inches from the shore off the Shetland coast.
The orcas, which can weigh more than six tonnes, were not shy as they approached David and Joanna Breeze, who were looking to catch a rare glimpse of the toothed whales.
They were travelling through the Shetland Islands on Monday when they encountered a series of orcas after trying multiple areas.
Two killer whales were spotted off the Shetland coast and they weren't shy and put on a quick show
The orcas continued to swim around in circles and David Breeze captured the moment he spotted the animals in the water
Mr Breeze spotted the pod of orcas after visiting a number of areas including Kirkabister, Nesting and Neap.
After reaching Neap, they spotted the animals who were first up to 30 metres away - but immediately swam right up to them.
Mr Breeze filmed the moment on his smartphone and uploaded it to video site Storyful and said: 'It was mind-blowing.'
He told the site: 'We didn't feel scared at all just awe struck, it was mind-blowing.
Diver and photographer Richard Shucksmith also filmed the group and said it was the 'best orca sighting I've ever experienced'
The pod of orcas (pictured) went up and down in front of the group who said it was 'mind-blowing' to watch
'At one point, two whales kept coming up and down in front of us blowing while the others swam back and to in the channel.
'These two did this for five minutes and were really focused on us, I don't think they were thinking we were dinner just curious of us. It was one of the best experiences of our lives.'
Meanwhile, diver and photographer Richard Shucksmith also filmed the group and said it was the 'best orca sighting I've ever experienced.'
He told the BBC: 'I can only imagine they were hunting seals or fish, trying to flush something out.'
